intro: Professor Emeritus Ph.D., The University of Texas at Austin Curriculum Vitae j.brown@austin.utexas.edu campus mail code: B7000 raising horses, tennis Jonathan C. Brown's book,Cuba's Revolutionary World, came out at the Harvard University Press in the spring of 2017. He has written four other single-authored books:A Socioeconomic History of Argentina(1979);Oil and Revolution in Mexico(1993);Latin America: A Social History(2005), andA Brief History of Argentina(2009). Three of these books have been translated and published in Latin America. One appeared in Chinese translation. His first book on Argentina, published at Cambridge University Press, won the Bolton Prize. Brown also has edited a collection of essays on workers and populism in Latin America and co-edited books on the Mexican oil industry and on Argentine social history.In 2023, the University of Pittsburgh Press will publish Brown’s study on the diplomacy of General Omar Torrijos to convince Washington to renegotiate the 1903 Panama Canal Treaty. Having seized power in a coup d'état, the Panamanian strongman took nine years to reach a deal on a new treaty, which he signed with President Carter. In his time, General Torrijos gained international acclaim like few other Latin American leaders. He died in a plane crash in 1981. Brown has a personal stake in this research topic, inasmuch as he once served as a US Army officer stationed in the Canal Zone.Research interestsProfessor Brown has begun two new projects. He is writing a volume comparing and contrasting the two Cuban revolutions of the twentieth century. Fulgencio Batista came to power following the 1933 Revolution, and Fidel Castro dominated the second revolution beginning in 1959. This study will explore the links between these two political upheavals and the differences between these two leaders.The second research concerns the twilight of Juan Domingo Perón’s political leadership in Argentina during the 1970s. Again, the researcher’s own experience becomes relevant. Brown was conducting his doctoral research in Buenos Aires when Perón’s death precipitated the Dirty War that eventually claimed the lives of some 20,000 Argentineans.Courses taughtU.S.-Latin American Relations, the Cuban Revolution, the Global Cold War, and the History of Argentina Jonathan C. name: David Crew
intro: Professor Emeritus; Distinguished Teaching Professor Ph.D., 1975, Cornell University Curriculum Vitae dfcrew@austin.utexas.edu GAR 2.126 campus mail code: B7000 History of popular culture and consumerism in twentieth-century Germany and Europe; history and politics of memory; visual history of Germany in the twentieth century, with specific focus upon photographic representations CURRENT RESEARCH AND PUBLICATION PROJECTS:At present, I am working on the following three book projects:Enigma in Black and White: Benno Wundshammer, Photo-Journalism and German History, 1939-1987This book project explores the life and career of Benno Wundshammer, a German war photographer, who produced images of World War Two that the Nazis used to promote their wartime propaganda. After 1945, he reinvented himself as a founding member of post-war West German photo-journalism. He is one example of an entire generation of so-called “Propaganda Company” photographers who significantly shaped the way World War Two was seen by Germans during the Nazi era and has been remembered since 1945. These photographers then played an important role in constructing the visual universe inhabited by West Germans during the early years of the Cold War. My current project takes advantage of an unusual resource, the extensive personal archive created by Wundshammer during his career, which is now part of the holdings of theBildagentur für Kunst, Kultur und Geschichte(formerlyBildarchiv preußischer Kulturbesitz-bpk) in Berlin.Disturbing Images: Photographing Hitler’s Third Reich, 1933-1945This book project explores the production and consumption of photographic images in the Third Reich. One of the Nazis’ main priorities after 1933 was to transform the ways that Germans saw the world and themselves. Although this project of reshaping popular perceptions and subjectivities employed written and spoken language, as well as music, it depended heavily upon images, particularly photographic images. The Nazi rise to power coincided with the breakthrough of photography and film as mass cultural and social practices in Germany. Between 1933 and 1945, millions of Germans took photographs and millions more consumed photographic images in illustrated magazines and went to the movies. What role did this unprecedented and pervasive visualization of popular culture play in constructing new views of the world that were consonant (or perhaps also in tension) with Nazi values?What Happens Next? Expectations, Hopes and Fears in German History, 1914-1989It is obvious that historians’ primary concern is with the past. But for Germans in the past what might happen in their futures was often as, sometimes even more important than what had already happened. This book will explore the varieties of ways in which Germans imagined what might happen next in the near and distant future. How did these imaginings affect the ways Germans behaved? On what sources of knowledge—past experiences, rumors, expert opinions—did Germans draw to decide what might happen next and how they should try to deal with these possible futures? This book will concentrate on the following periods of twentieth century German history: (1) the First World War, the German Revolution and the hyper-inflation of the early 1920s, (2) Hitler’s rise to power in 1933, (3) World War Two and the Holocaust, (4) the Cold War and the construction of the Berlin Wall in 1961. It will draw on personal diaries, letters and other so-called ego documents to reconstruct the great variety,inconsistencies and contradictions of  the ways in which individual Germans tried to grapple with the central question “What happens next?” CURRENT RESEARCH AND PUBLICATION PROJECTS:At present, I am working on the following three book projects:

name: Joan Neuberger
intro: Professor Emerita Ph.D., 1985, Stanford University neuberger@austin.utexas.edu campus mail code: B7000 Research interestsProfessor Neuberger studies modern Russian culture in social and political context, with a focus on the politics of the  arts. She is the author of an eclectic range of publications, includingHooliganism: Crime and Culture in St Petersburg, 1900-1914(California: 1993),Ivan the Terrible: The Film Companion(Palgrave: 2003); co-author ofEurope and the Making of Modernity, 1815-1914(Oxford: 2005); and co-editor ofImitations of Life: Melodrama in Russia(Duke: 2001) andPicturing Russia: Explorations in Visual Culture(Yale: 2008);Everyday Life in Russian History: Quotidian Studies in Honor of Daniel Kaiser(Slavica, 2010); andThe Flying Carpet: Studies on Eisenstein in Honor of Naum Kleiman(Mimésis International. 2017). Her bookThis Thing of Darkness: Eisenstein’s Ivan the Terrible in Stalin’s Russia(Cornell: 2019) was a finalist for 4 awards and won the American Historical Association's George L. Mosse Book Prize.
